reporting-org.narrative: Flemish Interuniversity Council for University Development Cooperation (VLIR-UOS)
Vlaamse Interuniversitaire Raad voor Universitaire Ontwikkelingssamenwerking (VLIR-UOS)

description.narrative: VLIR-UOS supports interventions that strengthen higher education, research and extension in various domains. VLIR-UOS works with several partners in Tanzania and supports projects (TEAM, SI, JOINT) and Institutional programmes in various regions of the country. All interventions frame with the VLIR-UOS Country Strategy for Tanzania, which was developed in 2012. It is based on multiple consultations of partners and stakeholders, and is in line with the needs of the country, particularly with the national development plan (National strategy for growth and reduction of poverty – Mkukuta). The VLIR-UOS country strategy for Tanzania has 4 central themes: ‘environment’, ‘health’, ‘food security’ and ‘entrepreneurship & business development’. As transversal themes, ‘gender’, ‘monitoring & evaluation’, ‘public-private partnership’ and ‘ICT & information management’ were identified. Two institutional university cooperation programmes are ongoing and part of the 2017-2021 programme. The programme with Mzumbe University focuses on "Governance and entrepreneurship through Research, Education, Access and Technology (GRE@T)", while the programme with Nelson Mandela African Institution of Science and Technology puts "Sustainable management of soil and water for the improvement of livelihoods in the Upper Pangani Basin" central. There are also four projects (2 TEAM projects and 2 SI projects) in the field of health and environment, which started as from 2017, in the framework of this country programme. A number of new projects for Tanzania will still be selected in the 2017-2021 period.

title.narrative: Tanzanian Higher Education Institutes have been empowered in their role as drivers of change by strengthening their threefold mission of research, education and extension (of new knowledge, applications and services) to society (continued).
Number of students or staff enabled in the areas of D4D (e-learning, ICT backbone/tools/services, library and information services) e-learning development
Number of PhD students graduated directly supported by the project, contributing to the objectives of the project

Number of students or staff enabled in the areas of quality management (internal/external) (research & tech. Transfer policy, quality assurance, scientific writing, statistics for research, academic English, human resources management)

Tanzanian Higher Education Institutes have been empowered in their role as drivers of change by strengthening their threefold mission of research, education and extension (of new knowledge, applications and services) to society.
Number of Master students graduated directly supported by the project, contributing to the objectives of the project
Number of articles published in national peer reviewed journals (through the support of the project)
Number of new or substantially updated Master programmes developed (curriculum) through the support of the project
Number of persons reached by presentations (community related) or extension workshops through the support of the project
Number of training module packages developed through the support of the project
Number of presentations (community related) or extension workshops organised through the support of the project
Number of articles published in international peer reviewed journals (through the support of the project)
Number of new courses developed through the support of the project
